AboutGeneral: The Pythagorean Theorem describes the relationship between the sides of a right triangle.

AboutMathTerm.Triangle: A triangle is a three sided shape
AboutMathTerm.Right Triangle: A right triangle is a type of triangle that contains a 90 degree angle, also known as a right angle
AboutMathTerm.Angle: An angle is a measure of the space between two intersecting lines where they meet
AboutMathTerm.Right Angle: A right angle is an angle whose measure is 90 degrees
AboutMathTerm.Hypotenuse: The hypotenuse is the longest side of a triangle, found opposite of the right angle in right triangles
AboutMathTerm.Square Root: The square root of a number produces that number when multiplied by itself, for example: 5 is the square root of 25
AboutMathTerm.Principal Root: When taking the square root of a number, there is both a positive and negative solution, the principle root is specific to the positive solution
AboutMathTerm.Leg: The shorter sides of a right triangle, also known as 'legs', are the two other sides that aren't the hypotenuse

AboutVariable.a: The variable 'a' represents the length of one of the shorter sides of the triangle
AboutVariable.b: The variable 'a' represents the length of one of the shorter sides of the triangle
AboutVariable.c: The variable 'c' represents the length of the hypotenuse

GeneralInventDate: The Pythagorean Theorem was discovered in 1900 B.C. in ancient Babylon and Egypt
GeneralInventor: While the Pythagorean Theorem was named after Pythagoras, a Greek philosopher, there is also proof that Babylonian mathemeticians discovered it around a thousand years earlier
GeneralRealUseCases: There are lots of use cases! One important consequence of the Pythagorean Theorem is the distance formula, which allows you to find the distance between any two points along a straight line
Pretty much any equation involving a square is also applicable to the Pythagorean Theorem
In Physics, an object's kinetic energy can be calculated with ```1/2 m v^2``` (m = mass, v = velocity)
In this case the kinetic energy from a car traveling at 50 mph is the same as the combined energy of two other cars of the same mass traveling at 30 mph and 40 mph
GeneralSpecificUseCases: Whenever you are dealing with right triangles, and need to find the length of a third side
